sources.title: 1954 - Jail Bait - Hidden Face - Ed Wood - VOSE
Jail Bait
sources.description: Jail Bait (1954) Directed by Edward D Wood Jr. A Howco Release A vicious criminal uses plastic surgery to escape the police.This movie features Steve Reeves (undubbed). This is the original version of the film released in 1954. This film was registered for copyright (1954 LP3883) and never renewed. It entered the public domain on 1 January 1983.

sources.title: Jail Bait
sources.description: Title: Jail Bait Summary: Vic Brady draws young Don Gregor into a life of crime. He then blackmails Gregor's plastic surgeon father into fixing up his face so he can evade the cops. Directed by: Edward D. Wood Jr. Actors: Production Company: Howco Productions Inc. Release Date: 12 May 1954 (USA) Aspect Ratio: 1.37 : 1 Vic Brady draws young Don Gregor into a life of crime. He then blackmails Gregor's plastic surgeon father into fixing up his face so he can evade the cops.

sources.title: Jail Bait (1954)
sources.description: Don Gregor, the son of famous plastic surgeon Dr. Boris Gregor, begins to hang around with young criminal Vic Brady and carry a gun. The pair attempt an armed holdup, and when things start to go wrong Gregor accidentally kills a night watchman. Fearing that Gregor plans to turn himself in, Brady kills him and blackmails Dr. Gregor into giving him a new face. Watch on RetroFlix:Â  https://retroflix.org/jail-bait-1954/

sources.title: Jail Bait (1954) Dir: Ed Wood, Starring Lyle Talbot, Dolores Fuller - Film Noir
sources.description: Jail Bait (also known as Hidden Face) is a 1954 American film noir directed by Ed Wood, with a screenplay by Wood and Alex Gordon. The film stars Clancy Malone, Dolores Fuller, Lyle Talbot and famed bodybuilder Steve Reeves, making his first major screen appearance in the film. Â  Notable for their campy aesthetics, technical errors, unsophisticated special effects, ill-fitting stock footage, eccentric casts, idiosyncratic stories, and non sequitur dialogue, Wood's films remained largely obscure until he was posthumously awarded a Golden Turkey Award for Worst Director of All Time in 1980, renewing public interest in his life and work. Â  Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jail_Bait_(1954_film) Suggested Film Noirs: http://bit.ly/2tLevkl The Internet Archive is an excellent choice for entire full length Netflix & YouTube style uploads of drama, mystery, thriller & crime noir movies from the UK & USA for free. Download complete online British & American classic black & white films from the 1940s & 1950s.

sources.title: Jail Bait (1954) | Colorized Public Domain Crime Thriller by Ed Wood with Steve Reeves & Lyle Talbot
sources.description:
Jail Bait (1954) is a gritty American crime thriller directed by Ed Wood, one of Hollywoodâ€™s most notorious independent filmmakers. This colorized and digitally restored version from Colorized Public Domain reimagines Woodâ€™s cult noir through high-quality visuals and modern restoration techniques, making it more immersive and watchable for todayâ€™s audiences across the United States, Europe, and beyond. The film blends criminal underworld tension with identity horror, exploring vanity, corruption, and the dark side of ambition in postwar America. By transforming the original black-and-white footage into vivid color, this edition gives a new dimension to Ed Woodâ€™s bold storytelling and the raw performances of Lyle Talbot, Dolores Fuller, and a young Steve Reeves.

Plot Summary:
The story follows Don Gregor (Clancy Malone), the reckless son of respected plastic surgeon Dr. Boris Gregor (Herbert Rawlinson). Donâ€™s thirst for easy money drags him into a world of crime under the influence of the ruthless Vic Brady (Timothy Farrell). After a botched robbery leaves a man dead, Don becomes a liability to his criminal associates, who plot to silence him before he can expose their operation. In a desperate twist, Donâ€™s father uses his surgical skills to perform a drastic operation that will change his sonâ€™s face â€” and his identity â€” forever.

As the narrative unfolds, the film blurs the line between crime and punishment, guilt and redemption. Dr. Gregorâ€™s moral conflict mirrors the ethical decay of a society obsessed with appearances. When Vic Brady turns on Don, the consequences erupt into a violent finale that delivers one of Ed Woodâ€™s most infamous and haunting endings.

Cast and Crew:

â€¢ Producer: Alex Gordon
â€¢ Screenplay: Ed Wood
â€¢ Cinematography: William C. Thompson
â€¢ Editing: Edward D. Wood Jr.
â€¢ Music: Hoyt S. Curtin
Starring:

â€¢ Timothy Farrell as Vic Brady
â€¢ Steve Reeves as Police Officer
â€¢ Theodora Thurman as Loretta

Film Significance:
Jail Bait stands as one of Ed Woodâ€™s most ambitious early projects, showcasing his raw narrative instincts and fascination with crime, identity, and transformation. Though often cited for its low-budget execution, the filmâ€™s script reveals complex themes of moral decay beneath the pulp surface. For modern viewers, this movie serves as both a time capsule of 1950s B-movie production and a precursor to later crime and horror hybrids. It also features an early appearance by future Hercules actor Steve Reeves before his international fame. The filmâ€™s experimental tone and eccentric direction give it an enduring cult status, solidifying its place among mid-century American noir curiosities.

Enhanced Public Domain Explanation:
This film is in the public domain, which means it is completely free of copyright restrictions and can be legally shared, viewed, studied, and preserved without limitation. Colorized Public Domain restores and enhances these historic works through careful digital cleaning, visual restoration, and colorization techniques. Our mission is to ensure that timeless classics like Jail Bait remain available to a worldwide audience. By presenting them in color and modern quality, we make them more engaging and accessible to younger generations who might otherwise overlook black-and-white cinema. This process respects the original film while providing a new layer of appreciation for todayâ€™s viewers.

Why Watch This Colorized Edition:
The original 1954 release of Jail Bait was filmed in stark black and white, reflecting Ed Woodâ€™s limited resources but ambitious vision. This colorized restoration enhances the filmâ€™s visual appeal for modern audiences, particularly those viewing on large screens and high-definition devices. The added color depth brings new life to the tense performances and postwar American atmosphere, allowing viewers to experience the noir world through a modern cinematic lens. This edition is perfect for audiences aged 55â€“64 in the USA, Germany, and Serbia who enjoy rediscovering restored classics from the Golden Age of cinema.

sources.title: 1954 - Jail Bait - Face-swap Heist:  She's A Good Girl... To Leave Alone!
sources.description:
When a troubled teen's petty crimes spiral into murder, a desperate plastic surgery scheme unleashes chaos. Spoiler: Bandages hide more than scars in this twisty tale!

Written & Directed by Ed Wood

Colorized version: https://youtu.be/xs3b1Fvjzyo

Cast:
Lyle Talbot - Inspector Johns
Steve Reeves - Lieutenant Bob Lawrence, Johns's associate
Herbert Rawlinson - Dr. Boris Gregor, a plastic surgeon and father of Don and Marilyn
Clancy Malone - Don Gregor, Dr. Gregor's son and an associate of gangster Vic Brady
Dolores Fuller - Marilyn Gregor, Dr. Gregor's daughter and Don's sister
Timothy Farrell - Vic Brady, a gangster
Theodora Thurman - Loretta, Brady's mistress

Genres: Crime, Drama, Film-Noir, Thriller
Release date: May 1954 
Filming location: Los Angeles, California, USA
